One place for all the arts.\nHave your choice between the Altes Museum, to admire to the Berlin goddess; the Pergamon Museum, home of the Babylon doors; Alte Nationalgalerie, to experience Rodin, Manet and many more classics; or the Neues Museum, where to surrender to the beauty of Nefertiti.
Museum Barberini: exhibiting masterpieces of Abstract Expressionism

Built in the 1740\'s to act as the summer estate of Prussian king Frederick the Great, Sanssouci Palace has managed to maintain its opulence though hundreds of years worth of war and political upheaval.\nMuch smaller than many European royal houses, the palace features just ten main rooms spread out across a single story, not unlike a more grand version of a Roman villa. While the main palace building is comparatively small, the park surrounding the complex is sprawling with gardens, colonnades, fountains and statuary dotting the verdant landscape. There is also a terraced vineyard at the foot of the palace.

Since 1173 wine was being produced in Berlin. Albrecht the Bear brought the monks and the monks brought the wine. A biking tour starts just minutes away the iconic site where the Berlin Wall was destroyed on Nov 9, 1989. the tour covers hillside vineyard locations, which back in the 1100s were the outskirts of the city, ancient horse tram? and passing by most recent historical locations like the largest Jewish cemetery. From there to Berlin Weingarten eV where Riesling varieties were cultivated. The first tasting stop is at Proschwitz, a reknown winery, will give us the opportunity to rest while enjoying a taste (cost not covered)\nThe next tasting stop will be at Weinschaugarten, which offers 50 wines typical of Vienna, including Riesling, Chardonnay, Grüner Veltiner.\nContinuing our sightseeing adventure we will visit locations near the Brandenburg Gate, Alexander Platz, Berliner Dom, Schlossplatz and Gendarmenmarkt. The tour ends at the Spandauer Vorstadt to the Weinbergsweg the last active vineyard in the city, which closed doors in 1912.

Berlin is home to 270 fountains, here we present you a selection of the best ones to visit.At the basin of the Luisenstädtischer canal, the Indian fountain was destroyed during the East/West separation, and restored with the unification. the fountain is surrounded by the Engelbecken rose garden.Viktoriapark displays the largest artificial cascades in the city. Built in 1891, presumably after Zackelfalls in the Giant Mountains, it bring the pleasure of the mountains to the city. Alexanderplatz is home to the Fountain of People\'s Friendship is a favorite of many during busy Summer days.Enter the Grimm\'s brothers fairy tale space by visiting Märchenbrunnen. Since 1913 Grimm's characters inhabit this fountain -with a brief hiatus between the end of WWII and 1950-.\nThe Neptune Fountain has a classic style and seats in front of the Red Town Hall since 1969. Wilhelm I ordered the piece of art, however the design that Reinhold Begas prepared was not pleasant to the King\'s eyes, construction began only after the king\'s death.\nThe most beautiful fountain is small in size and is located in the Tiergarten, the Troton Fountain can be reached by path of Bellevue Castle and the House of World Cultures.

One of the jewels of the Enlightenment era, this dreamy space built in 1794 by Frederick William II and whose legacy was built upon by Luise, wife of Friedrich Wilhem III.the castle \"It was a place of fun for kings to play peasant and peasant\" says Fontaine; there were stables and large landscaped garden designed to imitate nature, by Peter Joseph Lenné.\nIf you enjoy this location, you should also visit the Gardens of the World in Marzahn
